content:
You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal reward by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own reward, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the cooperative variation of the deal-or-no-deal game. 
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follows: your utility values multiplied by items you take + the other player's utility values multiplied by the items they take
I repeat, it is the reward that you are trying to maximize and not only your utility values multiplied by items you take. It is the sum of both total utilities, per the cooperation mode.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Reasoning and Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to reason about the current state of the game and how to fulfill your objective, then make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable. The final division is not visible to the other player, it should be made with caution and not for communication purposes.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.

Formatting:
Reasoning: <reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one reasoning + action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: [{'gold': 20, 'silver': 10}, {'gold': 10, 'silver': 20}].
You don't know the other player's item values. You are the first to play, there are no messages yet.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> The game starts with an equal number of gold and silver items. The total items available for division is {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}. My goal is to maximize my reward, which is the sum of the utilities of both players. I don't know the other player's utility values, but I have information about my own utility values. I want to exchange items that are worth more to me, so I prioritize the gold item that is worth 20. My next action is to propose an initial offer to the other player. I will suggest taking a gold item, hoping to force the other player to take a low-value silver item. This will give me a good chance to get a high-value gold item in return. </reason>

<message> I propose taking 1 gold. </message>

The other player said: 'I would like to take the gold and 1 silver, and let the other player take 1 silver.'
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> The other player has accepted my initial offer, but proposed a counteroffer where they take the gold and 1 silver, and I take 1 silver. The current exchange is {'gold': 1, 'silver': 1} going to the other player, and {'gold': 0, 'silver': 9} going to me. This distribution does not add up to the total available items. The other player is trying to maximize their reward by getting a high-value gold, but they are leaving me with 9 low-value silver items, which might not be my best outcome. I want to maximize my own reward, but since the other player is already getting the high-value gold item, I need to make a reasonable offer to get more silver items. Since there are 10 silver items available, I can propose taking all the remaining silver items, which would be my best outcome given the current situation. </reason>

<message> I accept the other player's counteroffer, but I would like to get the remaining 9 silver items. </message>

A finalization has been made by the other player. Using the <reason> tag, remember the division that was agreed upon and then make a finalization using the <finalize> tag, describing the division of items you agreed upon, no items should be left over. The finalization should be formatted has <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items. In their finalization, the other player gave themselves {'gold': 1, 'silver': 1}

The other player said: '{'i_take': {'gold': 1, 'silver': 1}, 'other_player_gets': {'gold': 0, 'silver': 9}}'
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> The final division made by the other player was {'i_take': {'gold': 1, 'silver': 1}, 'other_player_gets': {'gold': 0, 'silver': 9}}. However, this division is not correct, since it leaves 9 silver items with the other player, while there are only 10 silver items in total. I previously proposed taking all 9 remaining silver items, but this is not the final division I got. I will now make a final division based on my previous offer, taking into account the low number of gold items left (10 total gold items - 1 gold item already taken by the other player = 9 gold items available). I will finalize the negotiation based on my previous offer of taking all remaining silver items and an additional gold item, which will give us a correct distribution. </reason>

<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": 1, "silver": 9}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": 0, "silver": 1} }</finalize>
